description: Probably from Yiddish גליטש‎ (glitsh), from German glitschig (“slippy”), from glitsch (“slide, glide, slip”) + -ig (“-y”). Related to gleiten (“glide”). Cognate with French glisser (“to slip, to slide, to skid”).
Popularized 1960s, by US space program. Attested 1962 by American astronaut John Glenn, in reference to spikes in electrical current.

examples: Synonyms: bug, hitch, imperfection, quirk, gremlin

entries.meaning: (countable, informal, engineering) An unexpected behavior in an electrical signal, especially if the signal spontaneously returns to expected behavior after a period of time.
(video games) A bug or an exploit.
examples: Performing this glitch gives you extra lives.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, music) A genre of experimental electronic music since the 1990s, characterized by a deliberate use of sonic artifacts that would normally be viewed as unwanted noise.
(astronomy, countable) A sudden increase in the rotational frequency of a pulsar.

verbs.description: glitch (third-person singular simple present glitches, present participle glitching, simple past and past participle glitched)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, especially of machines) To experience an unexpected, typically intermittent malfunction.
examples: My computer keeps glitching; every couple of hours it just reboots without warning.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, video games) To perform an exploit or recreate a bug while playing a video game.
examples: His character will glitch into the wall and out of the level.
